questions.clue: This creature from Greek mythology is known for having the body of a lion and the head of a man.
In Scandinavian folklore, these beings are known for living in mountains and being unfriendly to humans.
This serpent is said to encircle the world in Norse mythology, eventually meeting its end at Ragnarok.
Known as the king of serpents, this mythical beast's gaze is said to turn people to stone.
This mythical Greek creature is part lion, part goat, and part serpent.
In 1876, Alexander Graham Bell was awarded a patent for this device, revolutionizing communication.
This device, invented by Tim Berners-Lee in 1989, became the foundation for the World Wide Web.
The first 1 GB hard disk drive was introduced by IBM in 1980 and was about the size of a refrigerator.
Developed in the 1960s, this programming language, named after a mathematician, became a standard for scientific computation.
In 1999, this short-range wireless technology standard was introduced, enabling the connection of devices like headphones and keyboards.
This Mexican street food staple consists of a tortilla filled with various ingredients like meat, beans, and cheese.
Known as 'satay' in Indonesia, this skewered and grilled meat dish is often served with peanut sauce.
In India, 'pani puri' is a popular snack consisting of hollow, fried crisp balls filled with flavored water and tamarind chutney.
This Middle Eastern street food is a deep-fried ball or patty made from ground chickpeas, often served in pita bread.
A popular street food in Vietnam, 'banh mi' combines a French baguette with local ingredients like pickled vegetables and meats.
This novel begins with 'Call me Ishmael.'
Identify the novel that opens with 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.'
The first line 'All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way' is from this Russian novel.
'It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen' is the start of this dystopian novel.
This novel's first line declares 'In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I've been turning over in my mind ever since.'
This physicist and chemist was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and the only person to win in two different sciences.
In the 1960s, this British chemist's X-ray diffraction images led to the discovery of DNA's double helix structure.
This American marine biologist's book 'Silent Spring' helped advance the global environmental movement.
This mathematician's work on the ENIAC computer was crucial to the development of computer programming.
This African American mathematician's calculations of orbital mechanics were critical to the success of NASA's first manned spaceflights.

final.clue: In 2007, this monument, a symbol of love, was designated as one of the New7Wonders of the World and is visited by over 6 million people annually.
